intro.title: Introduction to R
section.what_is_r.title: What is R?
section.what_is_r.li1: R is a programming language specifically designed for statistical computing and data analysis.
section.what_is_r.li2: Its philosophy emphasizes interactive statistical modeling and vectorized operations, allowing concise and efficient code.
section.what_is_r.li3: R is widely used in statistics, machine learning, bioinformatics, and finance, with a large ecosystem of community-contributed packages.
section.what_is_r.li4: R is open-source and maintained under the GNU General Public License.
section.what_is_r.quote: Think of R as the engine that performs statistical computations.
section.rstudio.title: RStudio: The Integrated Development Environment (IDE)
section.rstudio.lead: RStudio is not R itself, but an IDE that provides:
section.rstudio.li1: A user-friendly interface to write and run R code.
section.rstudio.li2: It provides a user-friendly interface to write and run R code, with built-in support for plotting, package management, and version control.
section.rstudio.li3: While RStudio is widely used, R can also be run independently without RStudio.
section.rstudio.quote: If R is the engine, then RStudio is the cockpit where you control and monitor the engine.

section.packages.title: Package Installation
section.packages.p1: R extends its functionality through packages (collections of functions, data, and documentation).
section.packages.p2: Most packages are distributed via CRAN, but others may come from GitHub or Bioconductor.
section.packages.install.title: Installing Packages
section.packages.install.code:
# Install from CRAN
install.packages("ggplot2")

# Install multiple packages at once
install.packages(c("dplyr", "tidyr", "readr"))
section.packages.load.title: Loading Packages
section.packages.load.code:
# Make a package available in your session
library(ggplot2)

# Check if a package is installed
require(dplyr)
section.packages.update.title: Updating Packages
section.packages.update.code:
# Update all installed packages
update.packages(ask = FALSE)
section.packages.other_sources.title: Installing from Other Sources
section.packages.other_sources.code:
# From GitHub (requires remotes package)
install.packages("remotes")
remotes::install_github("tidyverse/ggplot2")

# From Bioconductor (bioinformatics focus)
if (!requireNamespace("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE))
    install.packages("BiocManager")
BiocManager::install("GenomicFeatures")
section.packages.tip: Tip: Always check the package documentation with ?function_name or help(package = "pkgname").
